channel.title: WSJ.com: Economy
channel.copyright: Copyright © Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All rights reserved.

item.title: AUD’s Role as Economic Shock Absorber Might Fade
item.description: The AUD was floated in 1983 in the hope it would act as a shock absorber for the economy during times of global crisis.

item.title: China Services Sector Picks Up Slightly Despite Lower Orders
item.description: A private gauge of China’s services sector signaled that activity picked up in May, despite a renewed fall in new export orders.
item.dc:creator: Fabiana Negrin Ochoa

item.title: Some economists are beginning to question the accuracy of recent U.S. inflation data after the federal government said staffing shortages hampered its ability to conduct a massive monthly survey
item.description: The Labor Department says staffing shortages reduced its ability to conduct its massive monthly survey, forcing it to turn to less precise guesses.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: The Bank of Canada left its main interest rate unchanged, at 2.75%, saying the economy has softened but not deteriorated, and inflation has picked up steam
item.description: The Bank of Canada left its main interest rate unchanged, at 2.75%, saying the economy has softened but not deteriorated, and inflation has picked up steam.
item.dc:creator: Paul Vieira

item.title: U.S. Services-Sector Activity Unexpectedly Contracts as Tariffs Raise Uncertainty
item.description: The Institute for Supply Management said that its purchasing managers’ index for services providers fell to 49.9 in May, from 51.6 in April, in contrast to the small rise to 52.1 expected by economists polled by The Wall Street Journal.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Slowing Australia Economy Vulnerable as World Growth Stalls
item.description: Australia’s economy slowed sharply in the first quarter, leaving it vulnerable to emerging weakness in global growth.
item.dc:creator: James Glynn

item.title: President Trump’s tariffs threaten to crimp U.S. economic growth this year while boosting inflation, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said in a new forecast
item.description: The research group expects the Fed to remain on hold this year, as the economy is hamstrung by uncertainty over whipsawing U.S. trade policy, according to the OECD.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: The Bank of Canada is expected to keep its main interest rate unchanged Wednesday, setting aside signs of trouble in the job market and domestic demand to focus on core inflation
item.description: Job-market troubles, weak domestic demand to take back seat in Wednesday’s interest rate decision, economists predict.
item.dc:creator: Paul Vieira

item.title: BOJ’s Ueda Says Rate Hikes Will Only Come When Economy Is Ready
item.description: Kazuo Ueda said Japan’s central bank would make policy judgments without any preconceptions.
item.dc:creator: Megumi Fujikawa

item.title: Bank of England to Keep Cutting Rates But How Far, Fast Is Unclear, Bailey Says
item.description: Turmoil in the world economy in the wake of whipsawing U.S. trade policy is the main source of uncertainty, the Bank of England governor said.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: Eurozone Inflation Falls Below Target
item.description: Consumer prices were 1.9% higher on year in May, down from 2.2% in April, as the ECB moves closer to securing victory over inflation.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Global Markets Mostly Lower on Continued Trade Tensions; Eurozone CPI Data In Focus
item.description: Stocks and U.S. futures were down as trade tensions persisted ahead of eurozone inflation data Tuesday and an ECB rate decision later this week.

item.title: Switzerland Records Deflation for First Time in Four Years
item.description: Consumer prices were in deflationary territory in May, a milestone that raises the prospect of the Swiss National Bank cutting interest rates further later this month.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: ECB Set to Cut Rates Again and Keep Options Open
item.description: Investors expect a rate cut Thursday to be among the last in this sequence unless the eurozone economy is threatened by recession.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: The Trump administration wants to sell shares in Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. How it does so will have a big impact on home buyers and homeowners.
item.description: The Trump administration wants to sell shares in two government-controlled companies that are crucial for getting a mortgage. But it first needs to figure out what it wants the mortgage market to look like.
item.dc:creator: Veronica Dagher

item.title: South Korea’s Exports Drop as Tariffs Take Toll
item.description: South Korea’s exports fell in May, with shipments to the U.S. shrinking for a second consecutive month as President Trump’s sweeping tariffs hurt global trade.
item.dc:creator: Kwanwoo Jun

item.title: President Trump said he would double tariffs on imported steel, making the announcement at a Pittsburgh rally promoting a $14 billion deal between Nippon Steel and U.S. Steel
item.description: The president said U.S. Steel, which is in a deal to be taken over by Tokyo-based Nippon Steel, will remain U.S.-controlled.
item.dc:creator: Bob Tita

item.title: A court ruling that upends many of President Trump’s tariffs could blunt U.S. inflation and recession risks if it’s upheld. For now, it’s mostly heightening confusion.
item.description: A drop in tariffs could cut inflation risks and boost growth, some economists say. In the shorter term, expect more confusion.
item.dc:creator: Chao Deng

item.title: With President Trump’s trade strategy threatened by court rulings, his team is weighing a twofold alternative response
item.description: If a court appeal fails, the president’s advisers are considering a stopgap tariff regime.
item.dc:creator: Kim Mackrael

item.title: President Trump claims tariffs will make the U.S. rich. A coalition of states and small businesses argued the opposite in court and dealt a blow to his trade war
item.description: President Trump claims tariffs will make the U.S. rich. A coalition of states and small businesses argued the opposite in court and dealt a blow to his trade war.
item.dc:creator: Konrad Putzier

item.title: Governments will have to “work hard” to fix economic imbalances and roll back the spread of subsidies that have fueled challenges to the free-trade system, Bank of England Gov. Andrew Bailey said.
item.description: The head of the Bank of England says strains in the global trading system that have most recently been manifested in higher U.S. tariffs make life difficult for central bankers.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Pending Home Sales Slump as Mortgage Prices Weigh
item.description: The number of homes going under contract in the U.S. fell sharply in April, as high mortgage prices continue to hamper the market, according to a monthly index.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: U.S. Jobless Claims Rose Last Week
item.description: In the week through May 24, 240,000 people newly filed for unemployment benefits, compared with 226,000 the week prior and economists’ expectations of 230,000 claims.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: First-Time Home Buyers Downsize Amid Tight Supply, High Interest Rates
item.description: Home buyers are more willing to sacrifice size if it means finding a listing that works within their budget.
item.dc:creator: Denny Jacob

item.title: Sales of existing homes declined in April, after mounting economic uncertainty and steep housing costs pushed buyers away for the second consecutive month
item.description: The slowest sales pace for any April in 16 years indicates the spring selling season is shaping up as a bust.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Friedman

item.title: President Trump has pledged to bring more factory work back to the U.S., but many manufacturing jobs are already going unfilled
item.description: The president has pledged to bring more factory work back to the U.S., but many manufacturing jobs are already going unfilled.
item.dc:creator: Te-Ping Chen

item.title: The University of Michigan said Friday its preliminary index of consumer sentiment for May was 50.8, down about 3% from a final reading of 52.2 in April
item.description: The University of Michigan’s closely watched consumer-sentiment index was 50.8 in preliminary numbers for May.
item.dc:creator: Chao Deng

item.title: U.S. Housing Starts Ticked Up in April
item.description: The gauge of new residential construction rose 1.6% last month to 1.36 million, according to the Commerce Department.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Rebound Leaves Asset Prices out of Line With Geopolitical Risks, Says ECB’s De Guindos
item.description: Investors were again underestimating the risk of disruptions to the global economy, and a fresh bout of sharp price falls is possible, the ECB’s vice president warned Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Jobless Claims Fell Last Week
item.description: The Labor Department said that 228,000 filed new jobless claims in the week through May 3, down from 241,000 a week earlier. Economists polled by The Wall Street Journal had expected to see 230,000 new filings.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Major U.S. employers are starting to take a new approach to jobs: Hire less—or not at all
item.description: Most employers aren’t laying off workers, but many have paused hiring while the trade war plays out
item.dc:creator: Lauren Weber

item.title: The U.S. labor market steadily added jobs last month despite jolting tariff announcements that many economists expect will give way to a trade policy-induced slowdown later this year
item.description: The labor market steadily added jobs despite tariff announcements that many economists expect will give way to a slowdown later this year.
item.dc:creator: Justin Lahart

item.title: Heard on the Street: Fear of rising prices can make upfront purchases rational for some groups, but not all
item.description: Fear of rising prices can make upfront purchases rational for some groups, but not all.
item.dc:creator: Telis Demos

item.title: Americans are feeling gloomy about the economy after President Trump’s market-rattling first few months in office. But overall they are keeping the economy humming—for now.
item.description: People are still buying things at a steady clip, keeping the economy humming—for now.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Louise Ensign

item.title: American households ended April feeling much worse about the economy than they did in March, according to a closely watched measure of consumer sentiment
item.description: Households ended April feeling much worse about the economy than they did in March, according to a closely watched measure of consumer sentiment.
item.dc:creator: Harriet Torry

item.title: U.K. Consumers’ Mood Darkens Under Tariff Clouds
item.description: Consumers in the U.K. are growing more pessimistic as they fear the weight of trade tariffs and renewed high inflation, according to research group GfK.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby
